item.title: Upcoming news
Colorized portraits of the Night Witches: Soviet women pilots of World War II
item.description: This article highlights newly colorized photographs of the Soviet Union’s 588th Night Bomber Regiment, later known as the 46th Guards Night Bomber Aviation Regiment, revealing the faces and uniforms of its women pilots. Colorist Olga Shirnina brought life to original black-and-white images, offering a more immediate connection to the fearlessness and daily realities of these young aviators. Led by Major Yevdokiya Bershanskaya and formed under Major Marina Raskova’s initiative, the regiment operated primarily at night, employing a tactic of throttling engines to glide stealthily toward targets. The unit earned the coveted Guards designation in 1943 and carried the honorary title “Taman” for its role in the Novorossiysk–Taman operations. Over the war, the Night Witches flew roughly 23,000 sorties and delivered thousands of tons of bombs and incendiaries, despite using aging Polikarpov U-2 biplanes with limited payloads. item.title: Terrorist attack in Moscow kills Russian Army general, signaling vulnerability of security figures
item.description: A terrorist bombing in a Moscow neighborhood targeted the car of General Fanil Sarvarov, head of operational training for Russia’s General Staff. The vehicle exploded by a remote detonation beneath the car chassis, killing the general and triggering an intensive security response. Russian police opened a criminal investigation into murder by explosives, with investigators inspecting security footage, conducting forensics, and interviewing witnesses to reconstruct movements around the vehicle. Authorities consider multiple leads, including potential involvement by foreign intelligence services. Since the 2022 war in Ukraine, selective killings and sabotage against strategic infrastructure and security figures have risen, though the violence previously fluctuated between spikes and relative calm. The attack demonstrates that high-ranking military figures can be targeted far from the front lines, underscoring a symbolic dimension given the general’s role in operational readiness. The case

item.title: China's Poverty Reduction: Key Lessons from 40 Years of Progress
item.description: A new report highlights China's success in lifting 800 million people out of extreme poverty over the past four decades, contributing to nearly three-quarters of the global reduction in extreme poverty. The report, released by the World Bank and China's Ministry of Finance, outlines the drivers of China's poverty alleviation achievements and offers insights for other developing countries. Two primary strategies have driven China’s success: broad-based economic transformation, which raised average incomes and created new opportunities, and targeted support for disadvantaged areas and households. The report emphasizes the importance of education, infrastructure, and competition-friendly policies. China's approach, combining sustained economic growth with targeted interventions, has been instrumental in reducing poverty, and it serves as a model for other nations. Going forward, China aims to sustain its poverty alleviation efforts through rural revitalization, focusing on industrial deve

item.title: Florida Surgeon General Calls for Repeal of Vaccine Mandates with Support from Moms for Liberty
item.description: At the annual summit of the national advocacy group Moms for Liberty in Kissimmee, Florida Surgeon General Dr. Joseph Ladapo urged the organization to support efforts to repeal vaccine mandates for schoolchildren. He emphasized that the cooperation of lawmakers in Tallahassee is crucial for these changes. Ladapo spoke about restoring parental rights in medical decisions, aligning with the group’s mission to allow parents more control over vaccination choices. Moms for Liberty, founded in Brevard County, now has a national presence, and many parents voiced their support for less government intervention in vaccine requirements. However, some public health experts have expressed concerns over the potential risks of rolling back vaccination mandates, particularly with outbreaks of diseases like whooping cough and measles. Despite these concerns, parents at the summit expressed their desire for more flexibility in vaccination schedules and decisions regarding their children's health. Any si

item.title: Waymo Suspends Service in San Francisco Due to Traffic Chaos During Power Outage
item.description: Waymo temporarily suspended its autonomous ride-hailing services across San Francisco on December 20, 2025, following a large-scale blackout that disrupted the city. A significant power outage, affecting around 125,000 homes and businesses, caused traffic lights to fail, which created chaos for Waymo's fleet of driverless cars. Numerous videos surfaced showing Waymos halted at intersections, blocking traffic as human drivers navigated around them. The power outage, caused by rolling blackouts from Pacific Gas & Electric, led to widespread gridlock, and emergency vehicles faced challenges due to the confusion on the streets. In response, Waymo stated that it paused operations to ensure rider safety and allow clear access for emergency responders. The company confirmed the resumption of its services the following Sunday. This incident highlights the vulnerabilities of autonomous vehicles in real-world conditions, particularly when facing unpredictable scenarios such as power outages.

item.title: Countries Where Christmas Is Prohibited: Historical Prohibitions and Current Restrictions
item.description: The article surveys the concept of Christmas bans across history and geography, noting that Christmas is a public holiday in over 150 countries and celebrated by Christians who are a minority in many places. It traces periods when Christmas faced suppression, such as in Soviet bloc countries where religion was seen as disloyal to the party, and even in Scotland during the 17th century. It then highlights the modern instances where Christmas is restricted or prohibited, focusing on a small set of countries. North Korea is described as an officially restrictive religious environment where only the leader’s cult is permitted; December 24 is noted as a local holiday in honor of the leader’s grandmother, and December 27 as a constitution-related holiday. Brunei is described as enforcing Sharia law since 2014, prohibiting public Christmas celebrations, Santa costumes, carols, and Christmas trees in public spaces, though some consumer-related displays are allowed. item.title: Europeans Face 3 Billion Euros Annual Payments for Ukraine Loan Repayment
item.description: The European Union has devised a joint loan program to help Ukraine, which will ultimately cost Europeans approximately 3 billion euros annually starting in 2028. The loan will be used to cover Ukraine's massive economic and military collapse, raising a total of 90 billion euros over the next two years. While the EU initially considered using Russian assets to back the loan, this proposal was rejected in favor of joint debt financing. The repayment will be financed through national budgets and EU contributions, with payments beginning in 2027. Countries like Hungary, Slovakia, and the Czech Republic have opted out of the agreement, citing financial concerns. Critics argue that the EU should prioritize domestic spending on healthcare, housing, education, and pensions, rather than continuing to fund the war effort in Ukraine. Opposition has been growing as several EU nations, including France and Italy, already face large fiscal deficits, and additional debt could worsen the economic str

item.title: Masked Immigration Agents Raise Concerns Over Accountability and Abuse
item.description: Since President Donald Trump's return to office in January 2025, his administration has engaged in increasingly aggressive immigration enforcement tactics. A notable shift has been the widespread use of federal agents who operate in masks and without visible identification. These practices undermine transparency and accountability, contributing to a climate of fear within immigrant communities. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents, often in civilian clothes and unmarked vehicles, have been involved in arrests at sensitive locations like courthouses, schools, and places of worship. The rationale for masking is cited as a means to prevent doxing, yet this blanket policy seems to compromise the agents' accountability and transparency, which are crucial for upholding the rule of law. Human Rights Watch has documented numerous cases where individuals were apprehended by unidentifiable agents, creating confusion and anxiety. In one instance, a Tufts University student was detaine

item.title: Europe's Pursuit of Digital Sovereignty: Efforts to Reduce Dependence on US Tech Giants
item.description: Europe is grappling with its digital sovereignty, driven by a 90% reliance on US cloud services, according to experts like Cristina Caffarra. The US CLOUD Act of 2018 has created a direct conflict with Europe's stringent privacy laws, particularly the GDPR, as American companies are legally compelled to hand over data to US authorities, even if it’s stored in Europe. This situation forces European organizations to seek alternatives to US cloud providers to maintain control over their data and systems. A few public bodies in Austria, Germany, and France, as well as the International Criminal Court, are taking steps to regain digital autonomy by migrating to European solutions like Nextcloud and OpenDesk. The Austrian government, for example, has successfully moved 1,200 employees to Nextcloud, prioritizing control over cost savings. However, the shift is not without challenges. item.title: Judicial Inaction Enables Expansion of Book Bans Across States, Sparking Free-Read Rights Concerns
item.description: This piece argues that the Supreme Court’s decision not to hear Leila Green Little et al. v. Llano County effectively allows state and local authorities in Louisiana, Mississippi, and Texas to decide which materials are accessible in libraries, potentially eroding First Amendment protections. Citing PEN America’s tallies of thousands of book-ban incidents, the article contends that the trend reflects a coordinated effort by national conservative groups to remove or suppress books addressing race, gender, and sexuality, disproportionately affecting Black and LGBTQ authors. It portrays librarians as frontline defenders who have faced job losses for not removing materials, framing the issue as a broader civil-liberties battle rather than a local anomaly. The narrative weaves in the documentary The Librarians by Kim A. Snyder to illustrate how censorship campaigns operate at the local level as a testing ground for nationwide strategies, and urges civic engagement—voting, speaking out, or r

item.title: Belgium considers measures against climate misinformation and new observatory, sparking debate over information control
item.description: The article reports that on November 12, the Belgian government signed a joint declaration in Belem, Brazil, alongside other nations, committing to the integrity of information and the fight against climate misinformation. It notes that roughly fifteen countries have joined this effort. Beginning next year, Belgian radio and television outlets would undergo content reviews focused on weather reporting to identify misinformation, whether intentional or not. The piece presents this as the first step in a broader campaign to steer readers toward information approved by a new climate misinformation observatory, with possible future penalties or sanctions. The piece quotes minister Jean Luc Crucke discussing the aim to understand and counter the phenomenon without replacing existing regulators, and hints at potential future enforcement. The article references historical associations with censorship (nihil obstat) and likens the approach to medieval inquisitions, suggesting a crackdown on cl

item.title: Living Under Gang Rule in a Rio Favela: A Complex Preference for Safety Over Democracy
item.description: In an article for Haaretz, Yishai Raz shares his unusual perspective on life in a luxury favela in Rio de Janeiro, where a gang holds dictatorial control. While this might seem unsettling to many, Raz finds a sense of safety and order under the gang's rule. He explains that the strict enforcement of the gang's power, including harsh punishments for anyone who steps out of line, creates a secure environment where crime is minimal. Although he acknowledges the authoritarian nature of the gang's governance, Raz contrasts it with his experiences in Israel, where he feels democracy has failed to deliver the security and stability he desires. The article explores themes of governance, security, and the perceived failure of democratic systems in the face of societal instability. Raz's narrative challenges conventional ideas about governance and safety, raising questions about what people prioritize in their communities—freedom or security—and the role of democracy in achieving both.

item.title: A Historical Overview of US Efforts for Regime Change in Venezuela
item.description: This article provides an in-depth analysis of the United States' extensive efforts to destabilize Venezuela and promote regime change over the past three decades. It examines the political, economic, and strategic motives behind U.S. actions, driven primarily by the desire to control Venezuela's vast oil reserves. Beginning with the early 20th century, the piece details the role of U.S. corporations, such as Standard Oil, in Venezuela's oil sector. The Venezuelan nationalization of its oil industry in the 1970s marked a turning point, but the U.S. continued to exert influence. The rise of Hugo Chávez in the late 1990s and his policies of resource sovereignty sparked heightened U.S. opposition, including covert support for a 2002 coup attempt. Over the years, U.S. strategy shifted between low-intensity warfare, economic sanctions, and covert operations aimed at weakening the Chávez and Maduro governments. item.title: Belgium Leads EU Rebellion Against Seizing Russian Assets
item.description:
The article by Thomas Fazi analyzes the growing conflict within the European Union over Brussels’s plan to confiscate Russia’s frozen assets held in Europe. Belgium’s Prime Minister Bart De Wever has become a central figure in opposing this proposal, arguing that confiscating the assets would violate international law, undermine financial stability, and set a dangerous precedent. Most of these Russian reserves are held by Euroclear, a major Brussels-based financial institution. Legal experts, including Robert Volterra, have warned that such a move would be illegal and could trigger lawsuits that might bankrupt Euroclear and destabilize Belgium’s economy.
De Wever’s stance sparked strong backlash from EU officials and pro-EU media, accusing him of siding with Moscow. Yet, other countries — including Hungary, Slovakia, Italy, Bulgaria, and Malta — have joined Belgium’s opposition, fearing that confiscation could erode trust in the euro and cause capital flight. item.title: Israel's 'Zombie Economy': A Look at the Economic Crisis Amid the Gaza War
item.description: Since October 2023, Israel's economy has been severely impacted by the ongoing Gaza conflict, with a range of economic shocks that have affected both productivity and public services. Thousands have been displaced from border regions, while hundreds of thousands of reservists were pulled from the workforce, disrupting key sectors. Despite these struggles, some aspects of the economy, like the stock market and the shekel, have shown resilience, though they mask deeper issues. Economist Shir Hever describes Israel's economy as a 'zombie economy,' functioning but with no clear future due to heavy reliance on military expenditure, foreign loans, and denial of the situation. The nation faces significant debt, weakening international trade relations, and boycotts. More than 46,000 businesses have gone bankrupt, and nearly a quarter of Israelis are living in poverty, with rising food insecurity. Despite these hardships, military spending continues to prop up the economy, creating a façade of

item.title: Titan's Potential Internal Ocean Remains Uncertain
item.description: Recent findings have cast doubt on the hypothesis that Titan, Saturn's largest moon, possesses a global liquid ocean beneath its icy surface. While the idea of an ocean rich in ammonia and other compounds has been supported by Cassini's data, a new study challenges this notion by analyzing Titan's response to tidal forces. The original hypothesis suggested a liquid ocean nearly 250 km thick, but new research indicates that instead of a global ocean, Titan might have multiple layers of different types of ice, with potential liquid water pockets. Titan's unique environment, including its methane lakes and thick atmosphere, makes it a fascinating target for NASA's Dragonfly mission, launching in 2028. This mission will explore Titan's dunes and study a region known as the Selk crater, which may have once hosted liquid water and complex organic molecules, important for astrobiological research. The revised theory also suggests that Titan's current state could be the result of a relatively

item.title: Forest City: A $30 Billion Real Estate Failure in Malaysia
item.description: Forest City, an ambitious real estate project in Malaysia, was designed to house 750,000 residents and attract foreign investment, particularly from China. Launched in 2006, the development faced numerous challenges, including political changes, stricter regulations on foreign property ownership, and the COVID-19 pandemic. As of early 2025, the population of the city is a fraction of the expected number, with only around 10,000 people living in the area. Despite over $30 billion invested, the island city remains almost deserted, with many buildings and shops empty. Forest City is owned largely by China's Country Garden, which struggled with massive debt, and a local Malaysian investment fund. While the city is being maintained to look pristine, it has faced ecological and diplomatic concerns due to its location in the Strait of Malacca, a critical maritime passage. item.title: Morocco Expands Its Military Modernization Through Israeli Arms Purchases
item.description: Morocco continues to expand its military capabilities by purchasing strategic armaments from Israel, signaling a deepening defense relationship between Rabat and Tel Aviv. The article notes that Israel’s defense industry has broadened its client base from Southeast Asia to North Africa, with Morocco validating a new order for heavy artillery within the year. It mentions deployments of Israeli-made equipment in other regional conflicts, illustrating that international criticism of the Gaza war has not disrupted Israeli arms exports. Leading defense companies such as Elbit Systems and Rafael are highlighted as key players in this growth. Morocco reportedly made a significant investment, signing an agreement estimated at 150 to 200 million euros for ATMOS artillery systems, supplementing existing acquisitions like the PULS rocket launcher and the Barak MX air defense shield. item.title: The Health Crisis: The Consequences of Privatization and the Collapse of Public Healthcare
item.description: Michael Moore's documentary *Sicko* may be years old, but its relevance and impact have only grown since its release. In a recent blog post, the author reflects on the critical themes of the documentary and shares a poignant excerpt that highlights the dangers of the privatization of healthcare. The excerpt features a doctor who passionately discusses how the current trend of privatizing healthcare is leading to preventable deaths. As public healthcare systems collapse under the pressure of underfunding, more and more individuals are unable to access essential care. The doctor warns that this isn't an accidental outcome, but a deliberate policy shift that prioritizes private profits over human lives. Long waitlists, overcrowded primary care, and understaffed emergency services are just some of the deadly consequences of this shift. The post emphasizes that those who promote the dismantling of public healthcare systems are not just poor managers—they are complicit in a system that is ki

item.title: Impact of Satellite Megaconstellations on Space-Based Observatories
item.description: In recent years, the deployment of massive satellite constellations such as Starlink has raised concerns about their impact on astronomical observations, including those conducted from space. Initially, some suggested that moving telescopes to low Earth orbit (LEO) could solve the issue. However, a recent study published in Nature by Alejandro Borlaff, Pamela Marcum, and Steve Howell confirms that even space-based telescopes in LEO are increasingly affected. Currently, about 9,400 Starlink satellites orbit Earth, but projections suggest that by 2040 there could be up to 500,000 satellites, causing significant contamination of astronomical images. Already, 4.3% of Hubble Space Telescope images between 2018 and 2021 were affected. Newer satellites, such as Starlink v2 Mini, are larger and brighter, exacerbating the problem. Future wide-field and all-sky survey missions like NASA's SPHEREx, the Chinese Xuntian telescope, and the European ARRAKIHS could see up to 96% of their observations

item.title: Canada’s Controversial ‘Victims of Communism’ Monument Will Remove All Names
item.description: A year after its opening, Canada's Monument to the Victims of Communism in Ottawa is facing a major controversy over the names initially set to be inscribed on the memorial. A government report revealed that more than half of the 553 names planned for inclusion were linked to Nazi or fascist affiliations. As a result, the Department of Canadian Heritage has decided to remove all individual names and instead focus on thematic content that aligns with Canadian values of democracy and human rights. The monument, designed by architect Paul Raff, originally sought to commemorate the suffering of millions under communist regimes. However, its funding and connections to controversial groups, including Nazi collaborators, have sparked criticism. This shift in focus follows widespread backlash from Jewish organizations and media outlets who raised concerns about the individuals initially listed on the memorial. item.title: Airbus plans long-term move of mission-critical systems to a European sovereign cloud
item.description:
Airbus is preparing to launch a major procurement process to migrate some of its most sensitive and mission-critical applications to a digitally sovereign European cloud. The aerospace group plans to issue a request for proposals in early January, with a final decision expected before the summer. The contract, estimated to be worth more than €50 million, would run for up to ten years and is intended to offer long-term price predictability.
The systems targeted for migration include enterprise resource planning (ERP), manufacturing execution systems, customer relationship management (CRM), and product lifecycle management platforms that store aircraft design data. According to Catherine Jestin, Airbus’s executive vice president of digital, the information involved is extremely sensitive from both national and European perspectives, making digital sovereignty a core requirement. item.title: EU debates restrictions on Russian assets amid concerns over private ownership
item.description: The European Union recently decided not to seize Russian assets directly but instead approved a loan to Ukraine backed collectively by the 27 member states. Earlier, EU leaders, including Ursula von der Leyen and Kersti Kaljulaid, had pushed for a more aggressive approach to confiscate Russian assets, but concerns over legal, financial, and ethical implications led to a reversal. One consideration, reported by the Berliner Zeitung, is that while the assets are formally state-owned, they may contain funds belonging to private individuals, some of whom could be Jewish. This raises complex questions about targeting sanctions without violating property rights or international law, drawing historical parallels to the seizure of Jewish assets during the Nazi era. The discussion highlights the EU’s balancing act between supporting Ukraine financially and avoiding actions that could be considered discriminatory or unlawful. item.title: Hotel guest leaves room in extreme mess after two-year stay, prompting cleanup and renovation concerns
item.description: A hotel in Changchun, China, reported a shocking housekeeping scenario after a guest, described as a hardcore online gamer, checked out following a two-year stay. Staff recounted that the guest was rarely seen outside the room, and several workers did not know what he looked like due to his limited movements. Upon checkout, staff discovered an enormous mess: a three-foot-deep mountain of toilet paper, food wrappers, bottles, and takeaway containers cluttered every surface. The bathroom was severely littered, with tissues and discarded items covering the sink, and a thick brown grime covering the floor. A table and two gaming chairs were buried under waste. Cleaning required three days of back-breaking work to disinfect and restore the room. Despite the severity, management indicated no police report and no immediate plans to pursue responsibility, noting the guest still owed fees totaling nearly £300. item.title: European Commission discusses post-2035 rules for hybrids and range-extender vehicles amid pressure on the auto industry
item.description:
The article claims that the European Commission has reversed its previously announced plan to ban the sale of new cars with internal combustion engines from 2035, presenting the move as a major retreat from the EU’s climate agenda and a relief for the struggling European automotive industry. According to the text, this alleged decision would allow manufacturers to continue selling plug-in hybrid vehicles and electric cars equipped with gasoline-powered range extenders after 2035. The article frames the measure as provisional but politically significant, describing it as a capitulation driven by economic pressure, industrial decline, and growing competition from Chinese carmakers.
The piece emphasizes the difficult situation facing Europe’s automotive sector, noting that sales remain below pre-pandemic levels and exports are weakening. item.title: Minnesota Senate Bill Seeks to Include 'Trump Derangement Syndrome' in Mental Illness Definition
item.description: A bill introduced in the Minnesota Senate aims to modify the state's legal definition of mental illness by formally recognizing 'Trump Derangement Syndrome' (TDS) as a mental health condition. The proposed legislation, introduced during Minnesota's Ninety-Fourth Legislative Session, suggests amending Sections 245.462 and 245I.02 of the Minnesota Statutes to incorporate TDS alongside other recognized mental disorders. According to the bill, TDS is defined as an 'acute onset of paranoia' triggered by Donald Trump's policies and actions. Symptoms listed include intense verbal hostility toward Trump, difficulty distinguishing between policy disagreements and perceived pathological behavior, and acts of aggression toward Trump supporters or symbols associated with him. If passed, the bill would integrate TDS into the framework for case management and community mental health services. The measure is expected to provoke debate among lawmakers, with opposition likely from mental health experts

item.title: Germany Opts for U.S. MQ-9B SeaGuardian Drones Over European Alternatives
item.description: Germany has made a significant shift in its defense procurement strategy by approving the purchase of U.S. MQ-9B SeaGuardian drones for its Navy, moving away from European alternatives. The decision comes amid a broader defense spending spree, as the German Bundestag recently authorized over 50 billion euros for various military projects, including combat vehicles, artillery systems, and space-based assets. The MQ-9B SeaGuardian drones, manufactured by General Atomics, will be used for long-range reconnaissance and anti-submarine missions, supporting the German Navy's existing fleet of P-8A Poseidon aircraft. This acquisition effectively ends Germany’s involvement in the EuroDrone program, a European initiative led by Airbus for developing a medium-altitude long-endurance drone. Germany’s decision is seen as a blow to the European defense industry, especially given its historical leadership in the EuroDrone project and its use of Israeli-made drones in the past. item.title: EU's Sanctions on Jacques Baud: A Critique of Authoritarian Practices
item.description: This article reflects on the recent European Union sanctions imposed on Jacques Baud, a Swiss military historian and former intelligence officer, over alleged 'Russian propaganda.' The author, Martin Sonneborn, argues that these sanctions highlight the EU's increasing authoritarianism and disregard for the rule of law. Baud, who has written extensively on the Ukraine conflict, has been banned from entering EU territory and had his assets frozen despite having no financial ties to Russia. Sonneborn compares the EU's actions to a dictatorship, noting the lack of transparency, the inability for the accused to defend themselves, and the absence of legal processes. He also points out that similar repressive actions are being taken against others who dissent from the mainstream EU narrative on Ukraine and Gaza. Sonneborn criticizes Ursula von der Leyen's leadership, claiming the EU under her has strayed far from its founding principles of democracy and peace. The article ends with a philosop

item.title: The Congo Panorama: Colonial Propaganda and the Erasure of Belgian Atrocities
item.description:
The article examines how Belgium used cultural propaganda to conceal and normalize the brutal realities of its colonial rule in the Congo. It begins with King Leopold II’s personal acquisition of the Congo in the late 19th century and the international outrage provoked by widespread abuses, including forced labor, corporal punishment, and mass mutilations. Facing growing criticism, Belgian authorities sought to rehabilitate the country’s image through large-scale exhibitions that portrayed colonization as a benevolent and civilizing mission.
A central focus is the monumental artwork “Panorama of the Congo,” commissioned for the 1913 Ghent World’s Fair. Created by Alfred Bastien and Paul Mathieu, the massive circular painting presented an idealized vision of colonial life, emphasizing economic progress, missionary work, and harmony between Europeans and Congolese people. The explicit goal, as stated by organizers, was to make the public forget the scandals as quickly as possible.

item.title: Italian Deputy Prime Minister Criticizes the Impact of Sanctions on Russia on European Economies
item.description:
The article reports on statements made by Italy’s Deputy Prime Minister, Matteo Salvini, who strongly criticized the European Union’s sanctions against Russia, describing their overall impact on Europe as 'disastrous.' According to Salvini, the 19 sanctions packages implemented over nearly four years were intended to weaken Russia but instead have significantly harmed Western economies. He argued that these measures have contributed to economic decline across Europe and have notably driven up energy costs in Italy, placing additional pressure on households and businesses.
Salvini also warned against what he sees as the growing militarization of Europe, which he attributes to an exaggerated or 'phantom' threat posed by Russia. He questioned the strategic logic behind escalating military postures, suggesting that historical precedents demonstrate the futility of attempting to confront or defeat Russia through force. item.title: Globalized intifada? A critical examination of power, oppression, and technology in Western elites
item.description: This article, sourced from Rafael Poch de Feliu and featuring commentary by Jonathan Cook, argues that Western elites fear a globalized intifada not because of Jewish targets but because the idea itself challenges entrenched power structures. It frames the Palestinian struggle as emblematic of a broader anti-colonial and anti-elite resistance, suggesting that slogans like 'globalize the intifada' echo historical calls for people’s power against oppressive systems. The piece links modern surveillance tech, facial recognition, and militarized policing to a broader trend of control over everyday life, positing that these tools have been developed and tested in the occupied Palestinian territories. It further contends that Israel serves as a model for how elites might manage surplus populations in a resource-scarce, climate-threatened world, with dissent framed as antisemitic when directed at this dominant narrative. item.title: Logistics of the Great Pyramid: Insights from the Ro-She Khufu Harbour and Merer's Diary
item.description: The article explores the ancient harbour of Ro-She Khufu and the diary of Inspector Merer, shedding light on the logistics behind the construction of the Great Pyramid of Giza. Merer, a middle-ranking official, managed a team responsible for transporting massive limestone blocks from the Tura quarry to the Giza Plateau. His day-to-day records, preserved for over 4,500 years in Wadi al-Jarf, detail a sophisticated operation involving barges called imu, canals, and an artificial harbour basin to overcome the Nile floodplain's height difference. Ro-She Khufu, an engineering marvel, allowed the transportation of heavy stones using sluice gates and ramps, later complemented by mechanical pulley systems. The harbour served as an administrative and storage hub, accommodating workers, sailors, and officials like Vizier Ankhhaf. item.title: Karpathy predicts AI agents will need a decade to reach functional autonomy
item.description: OpenAI cofounder Andrej Karpathy expressed skepticism about the current state of AI agents during his appearance on the Dwarkesh Podcast. Despite the hype surrounding AI in 2025, Karpathy emphasized that functional AI agents are still far from reality and will require about ten years to overcome significant limitations. He criticized current agents for lacking sufficient intelligence, multimodal capabilities, computer interaction skills, and continual learning abilities. Karpathy highlighted that AI agents often cannot remember instructions or improve over time, making them unreliable. While many investors hail 2025 as 'the year of the agent,' he warned against overestimating AI's current capabilities. Karpathy envisions AI as a collaborative tool that aids humans in tasks such as coding, rather than replacing them entirely. item.title: China Tests Domestic EUV Lithography Prototype Developed with Reverse-Engineered Components
item.description: According to sources close to Reuters, China has developed a functional prototype of an EUV lithography machine, currently undergoing testing. This achievement is attributed to Chinese companies, including Huawei, who successfully reverse-engineered ASML's advanced EUV scanners and built a domestic version using second-hand parts. The prototype reportedly occupies a full factory floor, similar in size to modern High-NA EUV machines from ASML. The Chinese government initially targeted 2028 for producing working chips with this machine, but progress suggests it may come sooner. Huawei is leading this initiative to establish a complete domestic AI and semiconductor supply chain, reducing dependence on foreign technologies. The prototype employs laser-induced discharge plasma (LDP) technology to generate 13.5 nm EUV light, offering potential advantages over ASML’s laser-produced plasma (LPP) systems, such as reduced footprint, improved energy efficiency, and lower costs. item.title: Occupational Radiation Exposure and the Overlooked Risk of Indoor Radon in Spain
item.description:
The article discusses how public concern about radiation is often selective and poorly informed, focusing heavily on nuclear power plants or medical imaging while ignoring more common and sometimes more dangerous sources of ionizing radiation. The author begins by asking which workers in Spain receive the highest doses of ionizing radiation. Most people would assume radiology staff in hospitals or workers at nuclear power plants, both of whom are subject to strict legal exposure limits averaging 20 mSv per year. These limits are already several times higher than the natural background radiation received by the general population, which varies across Spain due to cosmic radiation and local geology.
However, the article highlights a surprising case: bank employees working in a specific branch in the A Coruña area who were exposed to extremely high concentrations of radon gas. Measurements reportedly reached 17,000 Bq/m³, leading to an estimated annual dose of about 428 mSv—far exceeding

item.title: Estonia Convicts Koos Leaders Over Pro-Russia Allegations Amid Crackdown on Dissent
item.description: An Estonian court has sentenced leaders of the Koos party to lengthy prison terms, accusing them of treason for allegedly working with Russia and posing a national security threat. Aivo Peterson, Koos cofounder, received a 14-year sentence, while Dmitri Rootsi and Andrei Andronov were sentenced to 11 years each. The defendants deny any ties to Russian intelligence, but the court did not accept their arguments. Prosecutors claimed the group issued proclamations supporting Russia’s foreign and security policies and deliberately aided Russia in activities against Estonia. The government has not presented evidence of direct Russian intelligence involvement, arguing instead that Koos advocates a pragmatic, neutral, and peaceful foreign policy, including calls for Estonia to withdraw from NATO and to disengage from the Ukraine conflict. The Koos platform also proposes Estonia’s withdrawal from the NATO-backed coalition supporting Ukraine. In Estonia and much of the EU, expressing opposition

item.title: IBM CEO questions the economic viability of large-scale AI data center investments
item.description: IBM CEO Arvind Krishna has raised concerns about the sustainability of the current investment trajectory in large-scale AI data centers. Speaking on The Verge's Decoder podcast, he highlighted that planned multi-gigawatt AI campuses could cost around $8 trillion cumulatively, requiring approximately $800 billion in annual profits just to service capital costs. Krishna emphasized that filling a one-gigawatt AI facility with hardware costs roughly $80 billion, and with companies planning tens to over 100 gigawatts in capacity, the financial burden grows exponentially. He noted that five-year refresh cycles for AI accelerators create compounding capital expenditures, as outdated hardware must be replaced due to rapid technological change and depreciation. Krishna also expressed skepticism about current LLM-centric architectures achieving AGI without new methods for knowledge integration. He believes that while generative AI can drive enterprise productivity, the massive scale of infrastru

item.title: 2025 Physics Nobel Awarded for Macroscopic Quantum Tunneling and Energy Quantization
item.description: The 2025 Nobel Prize in Physics has been awarded to John Clarke, Michel H. Devoret, and John M. Martinis for their pioneering work on macroscopic quantum tunneling and energy quantization in electrical circuits. Their research demonstrated that quantum effects, previously observed only at the scale of individual particles, can manifest in systems containing billions of particles. The team designed an experiment using superconducting materials separated by an ultrathin insulating layer, known as a Josephson junction. By cooling the circuit to near absolute zero and performing highly precise measurements, they observed a collective quantum behavior in the circuit, where the system tunneled through an energy barrier without the classical energy required. Additionally, they confirmed that the system could only absorb or emit energy in discrete amounts, verifying the principle of energy quantization. item.title: Leaked Documents Reveal Israel’s Use of Legal Strategies to Influence International Justice
item.description: A recent leak of over two million documents from Israel’s Ministry of Justice (MoJ), covering the period from 2009 to spring 2023, exposes how Israel allegedly deployed legal strategies to protect officials and the state from international legal scrutiny. The leak, claimed by a group named “Anonymous for Justice” and reported in April 2024, is indexed and publicly searchable through the nonprofit Distributed Denial of Secrets (DDoS). Amnesty International’s Security Lab confirmed the documents appear authentic. The majority of the files originate from the Department of Special International Affairs, established in 2010 and headed by Roy Schöndorf, who previously worked on legal justifications for extrajudicial actions. The department’s official role was managing international legal proceedings related to counterterrorism, while also developing lawfare strategies to advance Israeli interests and counter perceived misuse of legal tools against Israel. item.title: Investigations Reveal Corruption Risks Within NATO's Procurement Agency Amid Ukraine Conflict
item.description: The NATO Support and Procurement Agency (NSPA), based in Luxembourg, is facing significant corruption allegations involving bid manipulation, leaking of confidential information, and opaque contract management. Italian internal audit chief Gerardo Bellantone, who was dismissed after reporting abuses, played a key role in exposing these issues. Other whistleblowers, including NSPA Human Resources Director Geneviève Machin, have accused top executives, including Director General Stacy Cummings, of favoritism and inaction regarding corruption. With contracts worth €9.5 billion under her management, Cummings faces criticism for influencing decisions while ignoring fraud. The NSPA is now under investigation by Eurojust and several European states, highlighting long-standing vulnerabilities in military procurement, historically prone to abuse. Comparisons are made to past scandals like the U.S. Operation Ill Wind and Belgium’s Agusta-Dassault case. The article also discusses how Western offi

item.title: Lawmakers Warn Attorney General Pam Bondi Over Compliance With Epstein Files Release Deadline
item.description:
Attorney General Pam Bondi is facing intense political pressure from Democratic lawmakers over the Justice Department’s obligation to release the so-called Epstein Files by a court-mandated deadline. Representative Ro Khanna of California, a leading proponent of the Epstein Transparency Act, publicly warned that any attempt to conceal, excessively redact, or tamper with the documents could expose responsible officials to prosecution for obstruction of justice. His remarks were delivered in a video posted on X ahead of the 11:59 p.m. Friday deadline, emphasizing that no official, regardless of rank or political affiliation, would be immune from accountability.
Khanna stressed that the law requires a full and transparent release, allowing only limited redactions to protect victims’ identities or ongoing investigations. He underscored that the statute explicitly forbids redactions aimed at preventing embarrassment, reputational harm, or political fallout. While the legislation does not s

item.title: Legislative Palace of San Lázaro: History, Architecture, and Role in Mexico’s Congress
item.description:
The Legislative Palace of San Lázaro is the principal seat of Mexico’s legislative power and the permanent meeting place of the Chamber of Deputies, as well as the venue for joint sessions of the Congress of the Union. Located in eastern Mexico City near the historic center, the complex was built between 1979 and 1981 following a major political reform in 1977 that expanded the number of deputies, making the former legislative headquarters insufficient. The site previously housed the San Lázaro Railway Station, and its redevelopment formed part of a broader urban and public works program promoted during the administration of President José López Portillo.
Designed by prominent architects Pedro Ramírez Vázquez, Jorge Campuzano, and David Suárez, the building reflects minimalist and modern architectural styles. item.title: FBI Investigation in Colorado Springs Involved Undercover Surveillance and Alleged Entrapment of Racial Justice Activists
item.description:
The article details a secret FBI operation carried out in Colorado Springs during and after the 2020 racial justice protests sparked by the killing of George Floyd. According to reporting by The Intercept, the FBI, working through a Joint Terrorism Task Force with local police, used an undercover Colorado Springs police detective, April Rogers, to infiltrate left-wing and racial justice activist groups. Posing as a volunteer named “Chelsie,” Rogers gained the trust of activists at the Chinook Center, a community hub for organizing, and obtained access to internal records, emails, and personal relationships.
Once embedded, Rogers allegedly provided intelligence to the FBI and attempted to steer activists toward illegal activities, including gun-running schemes, mirroring tactics used by a paid FBI informant in Denver during the same period. item.title: Tesla organizes employee event in Berlin amid upcoming union vote
item.description: Tesla held a private event, called a “Giga-Event,” at its Gigafactory Berlin on December 2, featuring German rapper Kool Savas. The event appeared aimed at boosting employee morale but also served as a subtle anti-union campaign ahead of a critical work council election. During the performance, Savas attempted to hype the crowd by arriving on stage in a Cybertruck, changing lyrics in his songs to reference Tesla, and leading chants for Elon Musk. Employees reportedly remained unresponsive, creating an awkward atmosphere. Tesla management, including factory manager André Thierig, took the opportunity to criticize the IG Metall union while announcing a 4% wage increase. However, the union argues that salaries should rise by an additional 30% to match industry standards. IG Metall's chief, Otto, highlighted Tesla's long-standing strategy of encouraging employees to avoid unionizing in exchange for advancement opportunities, framing expansion plans as contingent on election results. item.title: Finland Publishes Annual Tax Records of Top Earners
item.description: Every November, Finland observes a unique tradition known as Tax Day, when the Finnish Tax Administration releases public data on incomes and taxes of the country's wealthiest individuals. This practice, rooted in the 'julkisuusperiaate' or 'principle of publicity', ensures transparency by allowing the public to access tax records. This year, the dataset included individuals earning over €150,000, roughly 1% of the population. At the top of the list was Mikko 'Miki' Kuusi, founder of Wolt and CEO of Deliveroo, with an income of €80.6 million, paying €39.7 million in taxes. Public access to such data enables informed discussion on income distribution and taxation. Observations reveal persistent trends, such as the underrepresentation of women among the highest earners, with only two women in the top 20. However, Tax Day data has limitations, as it does not include wealth from inheritance, gifts, property, or shares, and some dividend income may be tax-exempt. Despite these gaps, the tra

item.title: ICE Agents Detain Pregnant Woman in Minneapolis Amid Public Confrontation
item.description: In Minneapolis on December 16, 2025, ICE agents restrained and handcuffed a pregnant woman during a targeted vehicle stop, dragging her through snow and pinning her to the ground. Onlookers shouted warnings about her pregnancy, pleading with agents to release her, but one agent allegedly pressed his knees on her body while others used pepper spray against the crowd, including reporters. Protesters responded by throwing snowballs, and ICE called local police for backup. The Minneapolis Police Department later reported that no violence occurred against the officers. ICE successfully arrested the intended targets, a young Ecuadorian couple, while two U.S. citizens were also taken into custody for assaulting federal officers. The incident has raised concerns over ICE's use of force and racial profiling practices, particularly in light of previous reports involving the Somali American community. item.title: Russian military court convicts five members of a Marxist group in Bashkiria
item.description: A Russian military court in Ekaterinburg convicted five members of the so‑called “Marxist Circle of Ufa,” sentencing them to prison terms ranging from 16 to 22 years. The defendants include a regional parliament deputy from Bashkortostan, Dmitry Chuvilin, physician Alexey Dmitriev, retiree Yuri Efimov, and two veterans, Pavel Matisov and Rinat Burkeev. Prosecutors described the group as an organization preparing to overthrow the Russian government and accused them of distributing materials that urged violent seizure of power. The defendants disputed the charges, maintaining their innocence. All five have been in pretrial detention for over three and a half years. The verdict is not final and may be appealed. The case’s chronology suggests the group was detained in March 2022 after meetings at Ufa’s Stalin Museum, where they studied Marxist works and trained physically. The FSB allegedly infiltrated the group with a Ukrainian provocateur to record conversations. A discussion by Efimov r

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene Criticizes Trump’s Response to Reiner Family Tragedy
item.description: Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican congresswoman from Georgia who is leaving office in January, publicly criticized former President Donald Trump for his comments regarding the recent deaths of actor-director Rob Reiner and his wife Michele. The couple was found dead in their Los Angeles home, and their 32-year-old son has been charged with two counts of first-degree murder. Trump, shortly after the incident, posted on Truth Social referring to Rob Reiner as suffering from 'Trump Derangement Syndrome,' which Greene called 'classless' and inappropriate for a former president. Greene emphasized that the tragedy should be met with compassion rather than politicization, highlighting the family’s grief and the son’s reported struggles with drug addiction and mental health issues. Other politicians, including Republican Rep. Thomas Massie and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, also criticized Trump’s remarks. Authorities have indicated that the Reiners’ political beliefs were not a fact

item.title: Volkswagen closes Dresden plant, signaling deeper industrial and economic challenges in Germany
item.description: Volkswagen ended vehicle production at its Dresden plant in Saxony, marking the first permanent closure of a car factory in Germany after 88 years of operation. Described as a decision long anticipated as economically essential, the move underscores systemic weaknesses affecting Volkswagen, the German economy, and the global automotive industry. The company faces a projected requirement to fund approximately €160 billion over five years for electrification, software platforms, and new vehicle architectures. Historically, Volkswagen chose reductions in output or partial reconversions rather than outright plant closures, making Dresden’s shutdown symbolically significant as a showcase facility intended to demonstrate openness, innovation, and brand image. The company’s leadership, including Thomas Schäfer, acknowledged the decision as economically necessary rather than merely symbolic. Beyond Dresden, the decision signals to European automakers that Germany can no longer shield its indus

item.title: Personalized CRISPR Gene Therapy Enables Infant With Rare Metabolic Disorder to Reach Developmental Milestones
item.description:
The article reports on a significant medical milestone achieved through personalized CRISPR gene-editing therapy. KJ Muldoon, an infant born with a rare and often fatal metabolic disorder, has begun taking his first steps after receiving a one-patient, customized gene therapy developed by physicians at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP). A year earlier, doctors were uncertain whether KJ would survive infancy due to the severity of his condition.
KJ became the first person in the world to receive this type of individualized CRISPR-based treatment, designed specifically to correct the genetic defect responsible for his disorder. Before the therapy, his life was defined by prolonged hospital stays and constant medical monitoring. After receiving treatment earlier in the year, his health stabilized enough for doctors to discharge him in June, allowing him to return home with his family.

item.title: Minnesota Senator Justin Eichorn Arrested for Allegedly Soliciting a Minor
item.description: Minnesota State Senator Justin Eichorn, a Republican who recently co-sponsored a controversial bill to classify 'Trump derangement syndrome' as a mental illness, was arrested for allegedly soliciting a minor for prostitution. Authorities report that Eichorn, 40, believed he was communicating with a 17-year-old female online, but the person was actually an undercover police officer. He faces felony charges for soliciting a minor. Eichorn, married with four children, was taken into custody and booked by the Bloomington Police Department, who emphasized the seriousness of attempting sexual activity with a minor. The Minnesota Senate GOP and the state Republican Party both called for his resignation, citing the gravity of the allegations. The bill Eichorn helped sponsor drew national attention and criticism for potentially trivializing mental health issues and for its politically charged nature, defining 'Trump derangement syndrome' as paranoia triggered by opposition to Donald Trump. item.title: Iran Faces Severe Water Crisis Due to Overpumping and Dam Mismanagement
item.description: Iran is facing an unprecedented water crisis, described by experts as a state of 'water bankruptcy.' Years of poorly planned dam projects, overpumping of aquifers, and neglect of ancient qanat systems have drastically depleted both surface and underground water reserves. The qanats, centuries-old tunnels that sustainably tapped underground water, have largely fallen into disuse due to overpumping from modern wells, causing aquifer depletion and land subsidence. Iran's reservoirs are mostly empty, while rivers and wetlands have dried up, exacerbated by upstream dam construction in Afghanistan. Agriculture accounts for 90 percent of water usage, yet increasing numbers of wells produce less water than before. Hydrologists warn of impending food shortages, repeated water protests, and potential conflicts over water resources. Proposed solutions include restoring qanats, recharging aquifers, redirecting floodwaters, and shifting to less water-intensive crops, though government focus remains

item.title: Desmantelado un grupo criminal que saqueaba yacimientos arqueológicos en León y Valladolid
item.description: La Policía Nacional ha recuperado en León una valiosa corona visigoda de oro del siglo VI, junto a miles de piezas arqueológicas robadas, que habían sido saqueadas de importantes yacimientos de Castilla y León. La operación ha llevado a la detención de siete personas, que formaban parte de un grupo criminal dedicado al expolio de sitios como la antigua ciudad de Lancia, en León, y el yacimiento de Mayorga, en Valladolid. Los detenidos utilizaban detectores de metales de alta tecnología para extraer monedas, áureos romanos, fíbulas y otros objetos históricos, los cuales posteriormente vendían por internet o en transacciones privadas. Se estima que el valor de las piezas recuperadas podría rondar el millón de euros en el mercado negro. La investigación, que comenzó a principios de 2025, culminó con la incautación de más de 6.000 monedas, varios áureos romanos, y un importante número de objetos de valor histórico. Las piezas serán sometidas a un estudio técnico antes de ser depositadas en

item.title: Hackers Amateurs Deshacen las Redacciones de los Archivos de Epstein con Photoshop
item.description: En los últimos días, los archivos de Jeffrey Epstein publicados por el Departamento de Justicia han sido objeto de un método hackeado por usuarios en las redes sociales. Estos archivos, divulgados como parte de la Ley de Transparencia de los Archivos de Epstein, contenían numerosas redacciones en los nombres y detalles, pero los 'detectives de internet' han encontrado una forma de revertir estas redacciones utilizando Photoshop. A través de un truco, los usuarios pueden copiar el texto redacted y pegarlo en otro documento, descubriendo así información previamente oculta. Los usuarios han comenzado a difundir este método, revelando más detalles sobre las conexiones de Epstein, incluyendo menciones al presidente Trump. Este incidente ha avivado especulaciones sobre la relación de Trump con Epstein, sobre todo porque el presidente ha sido mencionado varias veces en los archivos. El Departamento de Justicia, por su parte, ha defendido las redacciones, asegurando que se hicieron para proteg

item.title: El tratamiento mediático de la religiosidad juvenil en 'La Sexta Columna' y su vinculación con movimientos ultracatólicos
item.description: El 19 de diciembre de 2025, el programa de La Sexta Columna dedicó su emisión a explorar la religiosidad entre la juventud actual. Aunque el reportaje pretendía abordar el tema de la espiritualidad y su auge, gran parte del tiempo se centró en las opiniones de personajes vinculados al catolicismo, como el presidente de la Conferencia Episcopal, obispos, periodistas de la COPE, y miembros del movimiento Hakuna. El programa mostró a jóvenes militantes y religiosos compartiendo su visión positiva de estos grupos, sin explorar suficientemente la relación de estos movimientos con la extrema derecha o su vinculación con la manipulación de la fe. José Antonio Naz Valverde, presidente de Europa Laica, denunció la falta de diversidad de opiniones en el programa, subrayando que el enfoque mediático distorsionó la realidad de la juventud española, dando una imagen distorsionada de la juventud como fervientes seguidores del catolicismo. Además, mencionó que el contenido no destacó la gran cantidad

item.title: Arrestado un empresario por explotar a dos trabajadores en condiciones extremas en Melilla durante más de una década
item.description: La Policía Nacional de Melilla ha detenido a un empresario acusado de trata de seres humanos y explotación laboral. Los dos trabajadores, de origen marroquí, llevaban años trabajando sin contrato, sin acceso a la Seguridad Social y en condiciones inhumanas. Uno de los empleados llevaba 16 años realizando jornadas de 11 horas diarias, desde las 4 de la mañana hasta las 3 de la tarde, con un salario que no superaba los 500 euros al mes. El otro llevaba 7 años en esta situación. Además, los dos trabajadores vivían en condiciones insalubres dentro del mismo local, sin baño, sin cocina y sin acceso a las mínimas condiciones de higiene. La investigación fue iniciada por una inspección de trabajo y, tras descubrirse la explotación, ambos fueron reconocidos como víctimas de trata y se activaron protocolos de protección. El empresario fue detenido y puesto a disposición judicial, enfrentándose a graves cargos por los abusos cometidos.

item.title: Análisis crítico de la supuesta subida de vacaciones y salario en Mercadona
item.description: El artículo de Laboro cuestiona la reciente noticia según la cual Mercadona ampliaría las vacaciones de sus trabajadores de 30 a 37 días y anunciaría una gratificación extraordinaria de 280 millones de euros para marzo de 2026. El texto sostiene que estas medidas podrían responder a objetivos publicitarios y a anticiparse a una futura reducción de la jornada máxima anual, que podría pasar de 40 a 37,5 horas. Se explica, con base en el Estatuto de los Trabajadores, que las vacaciones mínimas y la jornada deben ser respetadas por la empresa y que cualquier ampliación de días de descanso voluntario, si no está incluida en el convenio, podría tratarse de una mejora voluntaria susceptible de modificación o retirada. El artículo también analiza el funcionamiento del salario variable en Mercadona y la posibilidad de que la prima adicional dependa de condiciones subjetivas de valoración y de la voluntad empresarial, destacando que podría no ser obligatoria ni гаранizada para todos los trabajad

item.title: La ultraderecha europea aplaude el desafío de Trump a la Unión Europea
item.description: La nueva Estrategia de Seguridad Nacional de Estados Unidos reafirma los vínculos entre Donald Trump y la extrema derecha europea, una alianza que busca desafiar las instituciones de la Unión Europea (UE). Aunque las formaciones ultranacionalistas europeas celebran el ataque a la UE, su apoyo está matizado, ya que la injerencia de Trump choca con su propio ideario ultranacionalista. Líderes como Giorgia Meloni y Nigel Farage ven la estrategia de Trump como una oportunidad para avanzar en sus propios intereses políticos, pero reconocen las limitaciones de una cooperación que no ofrece un proyecto ideológico común. A pesar de las diferencias, los líderes ultraconservadores europeos aprecian la postura de Trump en temas como la inmigración y la defensa. Sin embargo, la ausencia de una agenda común plantea interrogantes sobre la viabilidad de estos vínculos. La percepción de Trump varía en Europa, con países como Polonia que lo ven como aliado, mientras que otros como Francia lo rechazan.

item.title: Facua denuncia a grandes plataformas por vender balizas V16 no homologadas
item.description: La organización de consumidores Facua ha denunciado a Amazon, AliExpress y Leroy Merlin por vender balizas V16 que no están homologadas por la DGT, a pesar de que los anuncios indican lo contrario. A partir del 1 de enero de 2026, todas las balizas de este tipo deberán tener conectividad con la DGT para ser válidas. Facua asegura que, aunque estas plataformas siguen vendiendo productos etiquetados como 'homologados por la DGT', no informan de que su validez caducará el 31 de diciembre de 2025. En su denuncia, la organización destaca que estas plataformas vulneran la legislación sobre la defensa de los consumidores, ya que no proporcionan información clara ni actualizada sobre el estado de los productos. Facua solicita a las autoridades competentes que abran expedientes sancionadores contra estos comercios online. item.title: Epstein menciona a Donald Trump en su carta de suicidio dirigida a Larry Nassar
item.description: Una carta firmada por Jeffrey Epstein, dirigida a Larry Nassar, ha sido recientemente divulgada y contiene inquietantes afirmaciones sobre el expresidente Donald Trump. En la nota, escrita tres días después de la muerte de Epstein, el financiero acusado de tráfico sexual menciona a Trump en relación con su afición por las 'jóvenes núbiles'. La misiva, con fecha del 13 de agosto de 2019, incluye un mensaje aparentemente suicida de Epstein, quien expresa haber tomado el 'camino corto a casa'. La Casa Blanca ha rechazado las acusaciones, calificándolas de falsas e infundadas. La nota, aunque no menciona a Trump de forma directa, parece aludir a él debido a su posición como presidente en ese momento. Esta nueva revelación forma parte de los documentos recientemente publicados relacionados con Epstein, que incluyen fotografías y correos electrónicos que sugieren la implicación de figuras públicas, aunque sin pruebas legales concluyentes.
